## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 278, 907, 294]]<|/det|>
9709/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 310, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 303, 907, 320]]<|/det|>
October/November 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 664, 215, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 96, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 76, 149, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 313, 102]]<|/det|>
Expand \(\left(1 - \frac{1}{2x}\right)^2.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 79, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 255, 143, 274]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 265, 798, 288]]<|/det|>
Find the first four terms in the expansion, in ascending powers of \(x\), of \((1 + 2x)^6\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 266, 920, 285]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 613, 186, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 612, 722, 641]]<|/det|>
Hence find the coefficient of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(1 - \frac{1}{2x}\right)^2 (1 + 2x)^6.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 617, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 873, 92]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = kx^{2} + 2x - k\) and a line has equation \(y = kx - 2\), where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 688, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(k\) for which the curve and line do not intersect.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 395, 92]]<|/det|>
Solve, by factorising, the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 100, 653, 119]]<|/det|>
\[6\cos \theta \tan \theta -3\cos \theta +4\tan \theta -2 = 0,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 267, 144]]<|/det|>
for \(0^{\circ} \leqslant \theta \leqslant 180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 127, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 83, 727, 351]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 368, 579, 388]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the graph of \(y = a\cos (bx) + c.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 400, 146, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 556, 419]]<|/det|>
Find the values of the positive integers \(a, b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 400, 920, 419]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 643, 146, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 643, 920, 678]]<|/det|>
For these values of \(a, b\) and \(c\), use the given diagram to determine the number of solutions in the interval \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 2\pi\) for each of the following equations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 686, 196, 705]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 685, 351, 710]]<|/det|>
\(a\cos (bx) + c = \frac{6}{\pi} x\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 688, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 808, 191, 826]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 804, 383, 829]]<|/det|>
\(a\cos (bx) + c = 6 - \frac{6}{\pi} x\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 809, 920, 828]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 848, 920, 866]]<|/det|>
<form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 83, 630, 230]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 250, 920, 300]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a metal plate \(ABC\) in which the sides are the straight line \(AB\) and the arcs \(AC\) and \(BC\). The line \(AB\) has length \(6\mathrm{cm}\). The arc \(AC\) is part of a circle with centre \(B\) and radius \(6\mathrm{cm}\), and the arc \(BC\) is part of a circle with centre \(A\) and radius \(6\mathrm{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 312, 148, 330]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 312, 673, 331]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the plate, giving your answer in terms of \(\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 312, 920, 331]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 690, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the plate, giving your answer in terms of \(\pi\) and \(\sqrt{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 583, 92]]<|/det|>
A circle with centre (5, 2) passes through the point (7, 5).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 398, 123]]<|/det|>
Find an equation of the circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 534, 529]]<|/det|>
The line \(y = 5x - 10\) intersects the circle at \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 540, 146, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 540, 465, 559]]<|/det|>
Find the exact length of the chord \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 540, 920, 559]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 400, 91]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 520, 751, 548]]<|/det|>
The result of translating the graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) by \(\binom{-3}{1}\) is the graph of \(y = \mathrm{g}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 560, 146, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 560, 710, 579]]<|/det|>
Express \(\mathrm{g}(x)\) in the form \(p x^{2} + q x + r\), where \(p\), \(q\) and \(r\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 560, 920, 579]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 92, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 680, 102]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \operatorname {f}(x)\), and it is given that \(\operatorname {f}'(x) = 2x^2 - 7 - \frac{4}{x^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 116, 146, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 115, 406, 135]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\operatorname {f}(1) = -\frac{1}{3}\), find \(\operatorname {f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 116, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
